title: SB 1073
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, adjusted by a factor for the taxable year. The earned income tax credit adjustment factor for taxable years starting January 1, 2015, is 0 percent unless specified otherwise in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only applicable when resources are allocated in the Budget Act for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The earned income tax credit is only operational when resources are allocated in the Budget Act for oversight by the Franchise Tax Board. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage vary based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income tax credit varies based on the number of qualifying children, with different credit and phaseout percentages for individuals with no qualifying children, 1 qualifying child, 2 qualifying children, and 3 or more qualifying children. Additionally, the earned income amount and phaseout amount also differ based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income tax credit varies based on the number of qualifying children, with different credit and phaseout amounts. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for joint returns and state-specific provisions. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified by changing withholding requirements for earned income tax credit and increasing the maximum credit amount to $3,400. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified to change withholding requirements for earned income tax credit. The maximum credit amount is increased to $3,400, and inflation adjustments will be recomputed annually starting in 2016. If the credit exceeds tax liability, the excess will be credited or refunded to the taxpayer. The Franchise Tax Board can establish rules to implement this section. Amounts refunded under this section will be treated like federal earned income refunds for determining eligibility for benefits under the Welfare and Institutions Code. The Franchise Tax Board is exempt from certain reporting requirements for implementing the credit for the 2015 taxable year. The Franchise Tax Board must comply with various reporting requirements for the implementation of a credit, including incorporating scope, costs, and schedule changes in the next Special Project Report. The Franchise Tax Board must include scope, costs, and schedule changes related to the California Earned Income Tax Credit in its next Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among working families and individuals, with annual reports on the number of tax returns and individuals claiming the credit. The Franchise Tax Board must report on the number of tax returns claiming the California Earned Income Tax Credit, individuals represented, average credit amount, and distribution by dependents and income ranges. The Franchise Tax Board must report on the distribution of credits by number of dependents and income ranges, including data on the number of families lifted out of deep poverty by the California Earned Income Tax Credit and federal tax credit. The Franchise Tax Board will provide a report to various Senate and Assembly committees regarding the California Earned Income Tax Credit. The tax credit will apply to taxable years starting from January 1, 2016.
